Description: Mould-made scarab in Egyptian blue; simply modelled and badly rubbed back, with elytra and prothorax lines barely visible; legs feathered at front and clearly modelled with undercut triangle at side; underside incised with motif arranged vertically with representation of robed figure walking to right with arms raised holding a knife in each hand, and flanked at his feet by cobras; longitudinally pierced; in blue paste of hard, rather coarse texture; surface worn out.
Curator's comments: This scarab belongs to a type which was produced at the 'Scarab Factory' (on its various productions see Webb forthcoming) and was widely distributed in the Mediterranean area, particularly in Eastern Greece, and Southern Russia (Gorton 1996, 121-127, type XXXIV, subtype B1-17, see especially B14 for this piece). Gorton identified the motif depicted on the underside as a standing figure holding two snakes, a rather common orientalising theme (Gorton 1996, 121). However, the figure does not seem to hold the cobras in his hands like one would expect from a Master of the Animals. For a rather similar motif on a scaraboid from Naukratis: BM 1886,0401.1690. Gorton, A.F. 1996, Egyptian and Egyptianizing scarabs: a typology of steatite, faience, and paste scarabs from Punic and other Mediterranean sites, Oxford. Petrie, W.M.F. 1886, Naukratis. Part I, 1884–5 (Third Memoir of the Egypt Exploration Fund), London. Webb, V. forthcoming, Faience finds from Naukratis and their implications for the chronology of the site, in R. Thomas (ed.) forthcoming. Naukratis in Context I: The Nile Delta as a Landscape of Connectivity. Proceedings of the First Naukratis Project Workshop held at The British Museum, 16th –17th December 2011.
Bibliographic references: Petrie 1886 / Naukratis. Part I., 1884-85 (pl. XXXVII, no. 130)
Gorton 1996 / Egyptian and Egyptianizing scarabs: a typology of steatite, faience, and paste scarabs from Punic and other Mediterranean sites (p. 123, fig. 29, type XXXIV B14)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (OE.37) (phase 3)
